content.description: <math alttext="The figure presents a one row table with 3 columns of data. The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. the maximum from 0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 1.2, of, the absolute value of the fifth derivative of f, of x, end absolute value, equals 8.4. Column 2. the maximum from 0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 1.2, of, the absolute value of the sixth derivative of f, of x, end absolute value, equals 58.8. Column 3. the maximum from 0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 1.2, of, the absolute value of the seventh derivative of f, of x, end absolute value, equals 411.8." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="12em 12em 12em" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><munder><mrow><mi>max</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>8.4</mn></mtd><mtd><munder><mrow><mi>max</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>58.8</mn></mtd><mtd><munder><mrow><mi>max</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>7</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>411.8</mn><mspace depth="3.0ex" height="3.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: Let <math alttext="P of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the fifth-degree Taylor polynomial for a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> about <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Information about the maximum of the absolute value of selected derivatives of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 1.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is given in the table above. Of the following, which is the smallest value of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which the Lagrange error bound guarantees that <math alttext="the absolute value of f of 1.2, minus P of 1.2, is less than or equal to k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>P</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1.2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
